_header: Flee from the press and dwell with sothfastness
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 414; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988, TP 404.5
_description: Chaucer, ‘Truth’ or ‘Balade de bon conseyl’ — four stanzas rhyme royal including Envoy, with refrain, ‘And trouthe the shall delyuer it is no drede’

BodArcSelB10.First Lines:
FLe from the prece & dwell with sothfastnesSuffyse vnto thy god
                    thoughe it be small…
BodArcSelB10.Last Lines:
…Weye thy luste and let thy gooste the ledeAnd trouthe shall
                    the delyuer it is no drede
BodArcSelB10.Attributed Author:
Ecce bonum consilium galfridi chaucers contra fortunam (f.
                        201v)
BodArcSelB10.Attributed Title:
Ecce bonum consilium galfridi chaucers contra fortunam (f.
                        201v)
BodArcSelB10.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             More Odd Texts.
Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 77. London: Trübner, 1886; repr. New York and London:
            Johnson, 1967.

BodArcSelB24.First Lines:
Flee from the pres and duell with suthfastnessSuffice vnto thy gude
                    thocht It be small…
BodArcSelB24.Last Lines:
…Wayue thy lust and lat thy goste the ledeAnd treuth the
                    schall deliuer this is no drede
BodArcSelB24.Facsimiles:
Boffey,  Julia,  and  A. S. G. Edwards, eds.  
             Chaucer, Works. Bodleian Library MS Arch Selden B.24: Facsimile
                Edition.
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1995.

Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Odd Texts of the Minor Poems.
             2 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st ser. 23, 60. London: Trübner, 1868, 1880; repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodFair16.First Lines:
fflee fro the pres and dwelle with withfastnes (sic)Suffise
                    vn to thy good though hyt be smalle…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…Weyve thy lust and let thy gooste the ledeAnd trouthe shall
                    the delyuer hyt is no drede
BodFair16.Note:
Second occurrence in MS; followed by note, ‘Qui legit
                        scriptorem non reprehendat’ (f. 201)

            London: Johnson, 1967.

BodHat73.First Lines:
Fle fro the prees and dwelle with sothfastnesseSuffise vnto thi
                    good though it be final…
BodHat73.Last Lines:
…Weyve thi luste and lete thi goost the ledeAnd trouthe the
                    shal delyuere it is no drede

OxfCCC203.First Lines:
ffle fro the pres and dwell wyth sothfastnesSuffyse vn to thy good
                    yef hit be small…
OxfCCC203.Last Lines:
…And wayue thy lust and let thy gost the ledeAnd treuthe the
                    schall delyuer hit ys no drede

CULGg427.First Lines:
Fle from þe pres & dwelle with soþfastnesseSuffise
                    vnto þyn þyng þow it be smal…
CULGg427.Last Lines:
…hold þe heye wey & lat þyn gost þe ledeAnd
                    trouthe schal deliure it is no drede
CULGg427.Attributed Title:
Balade de / bone conseyl (to left and right of line 1,
                    margins)
CULGg427.Facsimiles:
Parkes,  Malcolm B.,  and  Richard Beadle.  
             “Introduction.” 
             Poetical Works. Geoffrey Chaucer. A Facsimile of Cambridge University
                Library MS Gg.4.27. 3 vols Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1979 (vol. 1); 1980 (vols. 2-3).

             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967.

CULKk15.First Lines:
ffle fra the pres and duell with suthfastnesSuffice one to thi gud
                    þocht It be small…
CULKk15.Last Lines:
…Reull thi self that vthir folk can Reidand treuthe the sall
                    deliuyr that is no dreid

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
Fle fro the pres and dwelle with sothfastnesseSuffise vnto thi gode
                    þough it be small…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…Weyne thine luste and lat thi goste the ledeAnd trouth the
                    shall delyuer it is no drede Explicit

CamTCC600.First Lines:
fflee frome þe prees and dwelle with soþefastnesseSuffice
                    vn to þy goode þaughe it bee smal…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Weyve þy louste and let þy gooste þee ledeAnd
                    trouth þee shal delyver owte of drede
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
Balade by Chaucier [‘on his dethe bede’ added later] (p. 357);
                    Balades by Chaucer Made (RT)
CamTCC600.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             A Parallel-Text Edition of Chaucer’s Minor Poems.
             3 vols. 
             Chaucer Society
         1st. ser. 21, 57, 58. London: Trübner, n.d. repr. New York and
            London: Johnson, 1967: both texts.

BLAdd10340.First Lines:
ffle fro þe pres & dwelle wiþ
                    soþefastnesseSuffise þin owen þing þei it be
                    smal…
BLAdd10340.Last Lines:
…ffor þe & eke for oþer heuenlyche medeAnd
                    trouþe schal delyuere it is no drede

BLAdd22139.First Lines:
ffle fro the pres and dwell with sothfastnesseSuffice vn to thi
                    lynynge thogh hit be smal…
BLAdd22139.Last Lines:
…Hold the hie wey and lete thi gost the ledeAnd truth shal the
                    delyuer hit is no drede
BLAdd22139.Note: Immediately follows 4990 at end of MS

                    Goode though it be smalle…

BLCottCleoDVII.First Lines:
Flee fro the prees and dwell with sothfasnesse [sic]Suffice
                    vnto the thing though it be smal…
BLCottCleoDVII.Last Lines:
…Holde the high way and lete thi goost the ledeAnd trouthe
                    shal deliuere it is no drede

BLHar7333.First Lines:
FLe ffrome þe pes and dwell with sothefastnesseSuffice vn to
                    þi goode þaughe it be smalle…
BLHar7333.Last Lines:
…Weyve thi luste & lete thi goste þe ledeAnd trowthe
                    the shall deliuer it is noo drede
BLHar7333.Note:
The γ version (see Pace  and  David (1982)

            1982). Follows
                        Gentilesse (5277) on f. 147vb).

BLLan699.First Lines:
Flee from the press & dwell with sothfastnesseSuffise to thi
                    good thouh it be small…
BLLan699.Last Lines:
…War be thi lust & lat thi gost the leedeAn trouthe the
                    shal delyver it is no dreede

Incipit bon counceil de le Auctour (f. 82v); Explicit
                        optinus tractatus de ffortuna (f. 83v)

CovAcc3251.First Lines:
Fle fro the pres and dwelle with sothfastnesSuffice vn to thi
                    thinge thouȝ it be small…
CovAcc3251.Last Lines:
…Holde the hie weie and lete þi goost the ledeAnd trouth
                    the shall deliuer it is noo drede

Lam344.First Lines:
Fle fro the prees & dwell wyth sothefastnesseSuffyce vnto thy
                    good thought it be small…
Lam344.Last Lines:
…Weye thy lust and lete thy goste the ledeAnd trowyth the
                    shall dylyver yit ys no drede
